question: Should Israel recognise the Palestinian right of return?

content.source_1: UN General Assembly Resolution 194 (III), paragraph 11 (11 Dec 1948). Establishes the international normative basis often cited for a Palestinian right of return, calling for refugees wishing to “return to their homes and live at peace with their neighbours” to be permitted to do so and for compensation for others (UN Doc A/RES/194(III)).
content.source_2: Efraim Karsh, “The Palestinian Right of Return Is a Recipe for Israel’s Destruction,” Begin-Sadat Center for Strategic Studies (BESA), 23 Dec 2019. Argues against recognition on demographic and state-identity grounds, claiming mass return would eliminate Israel’s Jewish majority and thus its character as a nation-state of the Jewish people. https://besacenter.org/perspectives-papers/palestinian-right-of-return/
content.source_3: Geneva Initiative, “Refugees” chapter of the Geneva Accord (2003). Presents a negotiated-compromise model that does not endorse a blanket right of return to Israel but offers multiple remedies—return to a Palestinian state, resettlement/rehabilitation elsewhere, compensation, and limited, sovereignly controlled family-reunification into Israel. https://geneva-accord.org/the-issues/refugees/
content.source_4: Amnesty International, “Israel’s apartheid against Palestinians: a cruel system of domination and a crime against humanity” (2022), Remedies section. Advocates recognition of the right of return as an individual human right and a necessary remedy, referencing international human rights law (e.g., UDHR, ICCPR) alongside restitution and compensation. https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde15/5141/2022/en/
content.source_5: Salman Abu Sitta, “The Right of Return Is Possible,” Journal of Palestine Studies, Vol. 28, No. 2 (Winter 1999). Contends return is practically feasible, citing land-use and settlement patterns and the largely depopulated status of many original localities, and outlines mechanisms for phased repatriation and restitution.
content.source_6: Ruth Lapidoth, “Do Palestinian Refugees Have a Right to Return?” Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs (2001). Offers a legal counter-argument that GA Resolution 194 is non-binding and that general human rights instruments do not create a specific enforceable individual right for Palestinian refugees to return to Israel, emphasizing alternative remedies like compensation. https://jcpa.org/article/do-palestinian-refugees-have-a-right-to-return/
